--- title: "Wrangling Data" format: html: page-layout: full --- # Third Comparison: Base R vs the Tidyverse :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} Base R is the native tools that R has to deal with data. The syntax is outdated and better tools are available to use. The syntax to work in Base R is very similar to native python syntax. The biggest downside is that _it's not possible to chain operations together_ like selecting columns and filtering data. You would to constantly assign and reassign variables which results in very messy and unreadable code. If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don't make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse. Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required. ::: {.column width="10%"} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} The Tidyverse allows chainable actions like this: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} new_dataset <- dataset %>% select() %>% filter() %>% mutate() %>% group_by() %>% summarise() %>% arrange() ``` ::: Run this code in the console to download the tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("tidyverse") ``` ::: In order to be able to use this package, put this code at the top of your R Script or RMD file ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) ``` ::: ::: ::::

## Selecting Columns :::::::::::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Base R `df$column_name` `df[[]]` ::: ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% select(column1, column2) ``` ::: ::: :::::::::::::: ## Making New Columns :::::::::::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Base R `df$profit <- df$revenue - df$cost` ::: ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% mutate(profit = revenue - cost) ``` ::: ::: :::::::::::::: ## Filtering Data :::::::::::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Base R `df[df$temperature > 45]` ::: ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% filter(temperature > 45) ``` ::: ::: :::::::::::::: ## Grouping & Summarising Data :::::::::::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Base R I'm not sure how to do this in BaseR... and that's okay ::: ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} df %>% group_by(city) %>% summarise(Avg_House_Price = mean(house_price)) ``` ::: ::: :::::::::::::: ## Sorting Data :::::::::::::: {.columns} ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Base R `mtcars[order(mpg, -cyl),]` ::: ::: {.column width=\"45%\"} ###### Tidyverse ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mtcars %>% arrange(mpg, desc(cyl)) ``` ::: ::: ::::::::::::::

Check out [this page](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/base.html) for more comparisons. Filtering Data in Base R: - https://www.mitchcraver.com/2021/06/15/subsetting-and-filtering-a-data-frame-in-r/ - https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/crunch/vignettes/filters.html
